Also in this case, similarly to what we have observed in Section 4.3 of the main paper, when 10%percent1010\% of labeled real data is considered, both the Synthetic+Real and SSDA approaches improve over the Real-Only baseline for both in-domain and out-domain synthetic data. Better performance is obtained by SSDA with out-domain synthetic data with improvements of +4.15%percent4.15+4.15\%, +2.40%percent2.40+2.40\%, +5.60%percent5.60+5.60\%, +7.44%percent7.44+7.44\%, and +11.69%percent11.69+11.69\% for AP Hand, mAP Hand+Side, mAP Hand+Contact, AP Object, and AP Hand+Object, respectively. Furthermore, when 50%percent5050\% real labeled data is used for training, both the Synthetic+Real and SSDA models obtain improvements over Real-Only with in/out-domain synthetic data. Best results are obtained with the SSDA trained with out-domain data, which surpasses the baseline by +5.63%percent5.63+5.63\%, while the second best results come from SSDA trained with in-domain data with an improvement of +4.31%percent4.31+4.31\% over the baseline. These results confirm the effectiveness of exploiting the proposed simulator to produce visual data for training methods of Hand-Object Interaction to adapt approaches for in-domain applications.

Specifically, the SSDA approach obtains improvements of +6.97%percent6.97+6.97\%, +4.80%percent4.80+4.80\%, +11.36%percent11.36+11.36\%, +5.81%percent5.81+5.81\%, and +8.24%percent8.24+8.24\% for AP Hand, mAP Hand+Side, mAP Hand+Contact, AP Object, and AP Hand+Object, respectively. These results further confirm the effectiveness of exploiting the synthetic data generated by our simulator in reducing the need for real labeled data.

S3.T1.caption: Table 1: Statistics of datasets considered in our HOI-Synth benchmark. Note that the statistics reported refer to the training sets of the analyzed datasets.
S3.T1.table:
Dataset Images Hands Objects HOI
VISOR [12] 32,857 52,906 42,785 42,787
Synthetic 30,259 60,098 45,219 45,353
Ego-HOS [72] 8,107 15,015 11,393 13,659
Synthetic 8,107 16,101 12,170 12,129
ENIGMA-51 [50] 3,479 5,075 4,343 4,344
Synthetic-In-Domain 16,773 25,444 16,637 16,773
Synthetic-Out-of-Domain 20,321 40,135 27,499 27,370
references:
ENIGMA-51 [50] It is an egocentric dataset of subjects following instructions to repair electrical boards in an industrial laboratory. The dataset contains 12,597 interaction frames, 17,363 hand annotations, and 9,342 annotations of objects, with instance segmentation masks for the hands and objects. The dataset also provides 3D models of the manipulated objects and the industrial laboratory.
We complement this dataset with two sets of synthetic images: an in-domain and an out-of-domain sets. The in-domain set is generated using the 3D models of the environment and objects provided by the authors, thus obtaining synthetic images aligned to the real data. The out-of-domain set contains images of hand-object interactions in generic environments and with generic objects. Figure 3 reports examples of images from these two sets. The ENIGMA-51 portion of HOI-Synth allows to study the ability of hand-object interaction detection models to generalize to a domain-specific scenario in the presence of generic and domain-specific synthetic data.
Table 1 reports statistics of the training section of the HOI-Synth benchmark dataset, including the number of real and synthetic images, annotated hands, HOIs, and objects. We use the official validation and test sets of the respective datasets for evaluation.

Following [12], methods’ performance has been evaluated using COCO Mask AP [35]. Table 2 shows the results obtained by the considered approaches on the validation set of EPIC-KITCHENS VISOR [12]333Note that, in our implementation, the results of the HOS model differ from the ones reported in [12]. This is largely due to the fact that, for fair comparisons, we adopt a batch size of 444, the largest batch size achievable with domain adaptation models, to compare all approaches..
We assess performance with different amounts of real labeled training data to simulate scenarios where real data is scarce or costly to label and evaluate the generalization capabilities of the trained models.
When 0%percent00\% real labeled data are considered, the UDA approach significantly improves model performance across all the considered evaluation criteria when compared to the Synthetic-Only approach. Specifically, we observe improvements of +51.75%percent51.75+51.75\%, +41.09%percent41.09+41.09\%, +24.83%percent24.83+24.83\%, +7.12%percent7.12+7.12\% and a +23.45%percent23.45+23.45\% for the different metrics. These improvements confirm the usefulness of synthetic data when state-of-the-art Unsupervised Domain Adaptation approaches are used to mitigate the synthetic-real domain gap.
As the percentage of real labeled data increases, models trained on synthetic and real data either via pre-training (Synthetic+Real) or semi-supervised domain adaptation (SSDA) achieve consistently higher performance improvements with respect to baselines.
In particular, the SSDA approach achieves improvements of +5.67%percent5.67+5.67\%, +7.65%percent7.65+7.65\%, and +8.32%percent8.32+8.32\% over the AP Hand+Object metric when 10%percent1010\%, 25%percent2525\%, and 50%percent5050\% of labeled real data are considered respectively. Even in the configuration with 100%percent100100\% real labeled training data, SSDA improved the results over Real-Only by +1.15%percent1.15+1.15\%.
It is worth noting that with as little as 25%percent2525\% real training data which corresponds to only 8,215 images, SSDA achieves a AP Hand+Object value of 45.55%percent45.5545.55\%, i.e., a +0.22%percent0.22+0.22\% with respect to the performance of the Real-Only method trained with 100%percent100100\% of labeled real data (32,857 images). In general, methods trained on both real and synthetic data improve over the Real-Only baseline on most evaluation measures (improvements in blue), with small occasional deteriorations (in red) mainly for mAP Hand+Side.
Results of HOS on the ENIGMA-51 [50] test set. See the caption of Table 2 for a description of color coding.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3: Comparison of different adaptation approaches trained with synthetic data and 25%percent2525\% EPIC-KITCHENS VISOR labeled training data.
S4.T3.table:
Method Hand H+S H+C Object H+O
VISOR HOS [12] 89.98 84.67 55.88 18.49 38.19
MT [62] 88.78 84.40 60.94 21.89 43.69
MT+GRL [20] 88.64 84.27 58.21 21.82 43.97
UT [37] 90.60 84.49 52.55 22.11 44.32
AT [34] 90.37 84.42 52.59 22.15 45.55
references:
In Table 3, we compare the performance of different choices of semi-supervised domain adaptation approaches on EPIC-KITCHENS VISOR when the 25%percent2525\% of real labeled data are considered.
We choose this setup as a challenging benchmark for semi-supervised domain adaptation when the amount of labeled real data is limited. We considered the following methods: Mean Teacher [62] (MT), Mean Teacher + Adversarial Loss [20] (MT+GRL), Unbiased Teacher [37] (UT), Adaptive Teacher [34] (AT). In all cases, the methods are adapted to perform HOS by adding appropriate layers for the prediction of hand side, contact state, offset vector, and segmentation masks.

references:
Table 4 reports the results on the test set of Ego-HOS [72] when 0%percent00\%, 25%percent2525\%, and 100%percent100100\% real training data are labeled. The complete table with all the percentages of real data is reported in the supplementary material.
When considering 0%percent00\% real labeled data, UDA significantly improves over Synthetic-Only achieving +52.05%percent52.05+52.05\%, +43.28%percent43.28+43.28\%, +15.51%percent15.51+15.51\%, +8.41%percent8.41+8.41\%, and +21.00%percent21.0021.00\% across the different metrics.
When 25%percent2525\% real labeled data are considered, both Synthetic+Real and SSDA improve over Real-Only. In particular, the SSDA approach obtains improvements of +4.85%percent4.85+4.85\%, +3.66%percent3.66+3.66\%, +7.33%percent7.33+7.33\%, +1.99%percent1.99+1.99\%, and +3.43%percent3.43+3.43\% for AP Hand, mAP Hand+Side, mAP Hand+Contact, AP Object, and AP Hand+Object, respectively. Even when 100%percent100100\% of real labeled data are considered, the SSDA approach consistently achieves the best values across all measures, surpassing Real-Only by +1.19%percent1.19+1.19\%, +0.56%percent0.56+0.56\%, +0.18%percent0.18+0.18\%, +0.59%percent0.59+0.59\%, and +3.45%percent3.45+3.45\% across the different evaluation measures. It is worth noting that SSDA trained with only 25%percent2525\% real labeled data, which corresponds to 2,026 images, obtains an improvement of +0.52%percent0.52+0.52\% with respect to the Real-Only approach trained with 100%percent100100\% of real labeled data (8,758 images) considering the AP Hand+Object measure.
These results confirm the effectiveness of synthetic data in reducing the need for real labeled data, and as a way to improve performance over standard fully supervised methods.
It should be noted that Ego-HOS includes images of human-object interactions from different domains, including EPIC-KITCHENS, Ego4D, and THU-READ, and has a limited number of images, thus leading to a challenging benchmark for domain adaptation approaches.

Table 5 reports the results on the test set of ENIGMA-51 [50]. Experiments also compare results with in-domain and out-of-domain synthetic data.
When only synthetic data are used, the performances of the Synthetic-Only approach are greatly affected by the type of training synthetic data. Indeed, using in-domain data leads to an overall AP Hand+Object score of 12.85%percent12.8512.85\%, a +12.64%percent12.64+12.64\% with respect to the Synthetic-Only baseline trained with out-of-domain data. Similar considerations can be made when combining synthetic data with domain adaptation approaches. Indeed, UDA achieves a remarkable 34.78%percent34.7834.78\% AP Hand+Object without seeing a single labeled real image, a +21.93%percent21.93+21.93\% with respect to Synthetic-Only.
